verses.text: These are the men who came to David at Ziklag, while he was kept apart because of Saul son of Kish. They were among the warriors helping David in battle.
verses.comment: Ziklag was given to David by the Philistine king Achish, showing God's providence in preserving David for kingship. The narrative highlights David's gathering of loyal followers even before his official reign, foreshadowing the unity that would later be established in the nation.

verses.text: They were skilled in using the bow, and could shoot arrows or sling stones with either their right or left hand. They were Benjamites, Saul's own kinsmen.
verses.comment: David's supporters included relatives of Saul, indicating reconciliation and the legitimacy of David's future kingship through the acceptance of his predecessor's tribe.

verses.text: Their leader was Ahiezer, with Joash, both sons of Shemaah the Gibeathite; also Jeziel and Pelet, sons of Azmaveth; Beracah, Jehu from Anathoth;
verses.comment: The listing of leaders emphasizes the faithful remnant preserved for God's purposes. The pattern of naming shows the importance of tradition, memory, and continuity in the story of salvation.

verses.text: Ishmaiah from Gibeon, a warrior among the Thirty and their leader; Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, Jozabad from Gederah;
verses.comment: Having warriors from various places points to the gathering of all Israel under David's leadership, symbolizing universal unity under one king.

verses.text: Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, Shemariah, Shephatiah the Haruphite;
verses.comment: The multiplicity of tribes and families joining David reflects unity and the fulfillment of God’s promise for one shepherd for Israel. Tradition is strengthened by personal dedication.

verses.text: Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, Jashobeam the Korahites;
verses.comment: Members of priestly descent (the Korahites) joining David prefigure the cooperation of priesthood and kingship, later fulfilled perfectly in Christ.

verses.text: and Joelah and Zebadiah, sons of Jeroham from Gedor.
verses.comment: By emphasizing lineage, the Chronicler affirms the importance of family in God's saving plan.

verses.text: Some Gadites separated themselves to David at his stronghold in the wilderness, mighty men of valor, trained for war, able to handle shield and spear. Their faces were as fierce as lions, and they were as swift as gazelles on the mountains.
verses.comment: The desert location recalls biblical times of testing, resembling Moses and Elijah in the wilderness, preparing for greater calling. Swift as gazelles symbolizes readiness to respond to God's call.

verses.text: Ezer was the chief, Obadiah the second, Eliab the third, Mishmannah the fourth, Jeremiah the fifth,
verses.comment: List of names signals hierarchical leadership, showing order and necessary structure within the people of God.

verses.text: Attai the sixth, Eliel the seventh,
verses.comment: This precise enumeration underlines the value of each individual's contribution to the corporate mission of God's people.

verses.text: Johanan the eighth, Elzabad the ninth,
verses.comment: The names of these warriors have been preserved for posterity, expressing the enduring legacy of faith.

verses.text: Jeremiah the tenth, Machbannai the eleventh.
verses.comment: The careful count and recording reflect God's attention to every detail in His plan.

verses.text: These Gadites were captains of the army; the least had charge of a hundred, and the greatest of a thousand.
verses.comment: Hierarchy and structure are essential to both military and spiritual authority, with leaders appointed by divine providence.

verses.text: These are the ones who crossed the Jordan in the first month, when it was overflowing all its banks, and they put to flight all the people in the valleys, east and west.
verses.comment: Crossing when the river is at flood recalls Joshua’s entrance to the Promised Land, pointing to faith overcoming obstacles—essential for spiritual progress.

verses.text: And some from the tribe of Benjamin and Judah came to David at the stronghold.
verses.comment: The joining of these two central tribes prefigures unity and foreshadows the spiritual harmony God desires among believers.

verses.text: David went out to meet them and said to them, 'If you have come to me in peace to help me, my heart will be joined with you. But if you have come to betray me to my enemies, though my hands are innocent, may the God of our ancestors look upon it and judge.'
verses.comment: David’s trust in God’s judgment over his innocence and the motives of others contrasts human suspicion with divine justice and discernment.

verses.text: Then the Spirit came upon Amasai, chief of the Thirty, and he said, 'We are yours, David! We are with you, son of Jesse! Peace, peace to you, and peace to those who help you, for your God helps you.' So David received them and made them leaders of his troops.
verses.comment: Amasai speaks by the Spirit, affirming David's anointing and divine mission, hinting at the principle of apostolic succession and Spirit-led support for God's chosen leaders.

verses.text: From Manasseh, some defected to David when he came with the Philistines for battle against Saul. But he did not help the Philistines, because after discussion, their rulers sent him away, saying, 'He might defect to his master Saul and endanger us.'
verses.comment: David’s refusal to fight against Israel underlines his respect for God’s anointed and integrity, anticipating the refusal of Jesus to use force for personal gain.

verses.text: When David was returning to Ziklag, those from Manasseh who joined him were Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai, leaders of units of thousands in Manasseh.
verses.comment: David continually draws new followers, even in times of displacement, pointing to the attractive power of God’s anointed and foreshadowing Christ’s drawing of disciples.

verses.text: They helped David against raiding bands, for all of them were mighty men of valor, and they became commanders in his army.
verses.comment: Active assistance in defending God’s people is a mark of true fellowship; participation in mission requires sacrifice and courage.

verses.text: Every day men came to David to help him, until his army became great, like the army of God.
verses.comment: The description 'like the army of God' suggests both human and angelic hosts, highlighting that God can raise up spiritual armies for his purposes.

verses.text: These are the numbers of the men armed for battle who came to David at Hebron to turn Saul’s kingdom over to him, as the LORD had spoken:
verses.comment: David’s kingship comes through fulfillment of prophecy, showing the authority rests not merely in human assent but in God’s Word. The idea of kingdom transfer prefigures the establishment of Christ’s reign.

verses.text: From Judah, carrying shield and spear: 6,800 armed for war.
verses.comment: The strength of Judah is central, connecting to the messianic lineage (Genesis 49:10); from this tribe, the true King will come.

verses.text: From Simeon: mighty men of war, 7,100.
verses.comment: Simeon, though often a minor tribe, shows that all are welcome in service to God’s chosen ruler.

verses.text: From Levi: 4,600.
verses.comment: Levitical support implies priestly blessing on David’s kingship, foreshadowing the unity of spiritual and royal authority.

verses.text: Besides Jehoiada, leader of the house of Aaron, and with him 3,700 men;
verses.comment: Aaron’s descendants joining David signal continuity of worship, showing that divine service and leadership work together in God’s plan.

verses.text: And Zadok, a young man of remarkable strength, with 22 officers from his own family.
verses.comment: Zadok eventually becomes a high priest, signaling enduring fidelity, and the lasting structure of priesthood supporting the true king.

verses.text: From Benjamin, Saul’s own tribe: 3,000. Most of them remained loyal to Saul’s house until then.
verses.comment: Benjamin’s continued but eventual support displays the slow process of conversion and reconciliation—God’s work of bringing wayward hearts to allegiance.

verses.text: From Ephraim: 20,800 valiant men, famous throughout their families.
verses.comment: Ephraim, symbolic of lost tribes returned, illustrates the restoration offered when God’s messiah comes to reign.

verses.text: From half the tribe of Manasseh: 18,000, chosen by name to come and make David king.
verses.comment: Being chosen by name recalls the election of God's saints by divine decree, emphasizing God’s personal call to service.

verses.text: From Issachar, men who understood the times and knew what Israel should do—200 chiefs, with all their relatives under their command.
verses.comment: Issachar’s wisdom and discernment illustrate the importance of spiritual insight in leadership and guidance, paralleling the Church’s mission to teach and guard the faith.

verses.text: From Zebulun, those prepared for battle, with every kind of weapon—50,000, able to keep rank, not double-hearted.
verses.comment: Steadfastness and unity are key marks of discipleship, manifesting the oneness Christ prayed for (John 17:20-23).

verses.text: From Naphtali: 1,000 officers, and with them 37,000 equipped with shield and spear.
verses.comment: Naphtali’s contribution demonstrates that every group, regardless of origin or size, has a part in the kingdom of God.

verses.text: From Dan: 28,600 men ready for battle.
verses.comment: Full participation of every tribe reflects the ideal of unity and fullness in the people assembled as the army of the Lord.

verses.text: From Asher: 40,000 trained men, ready for battle.
verses.comment: Skill and preparation are valued, paralleling spiritual disciplines and readiness in discipleship.

verses.text: Across the Jordan, from Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh: 120,000 armed with every kind of weapon for war.
verses.comment: Inter-tribal cooperation points to the universal reach of God’s chosen ruler, with all nations eventually brought into the kingdom.

verses.text: All these warriors came to Hebron with a single purpose: to make David king over all Israel. All the rest of Israel were united in their desire to make David king.
verses.comment: The union under David anticipates the fulfillment of unity under Christ, where all believers are gathered under a single head (cf. John 17:21).

verses.text: They spent three days with David eating and drinking, for their relatives had provided for them.
verses.comment: Feasting in covenant establishes fellowship and joy, prefiguring the Eucharistic celebration where unity and thanksgiving are experienced.

verses.text: Their neighbors from as far as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali came bringing food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen—flour, pressed figs, raisins, wine, oil, cattle, and sheep in abundance, for there was joy in Israel.
verses.comment: The abundant provision and joy marks the blessing of unity under God’s anointed leader; generosity and communal life reflect heavenly realities enjoyed in full unity.

verses.text: There was great rejoicing throughout all Israel.
verses.comment: The unity and joy anticipated in David's kingship foreshadows the fullness of joy in Christ's reign, a unity that is meant to embrace all the faithful in one spiritual family.
